member.name: M:GenHTTP.Utilities.Setting.ConvertTo``1(``0)
member.summary: Try to convert the value of this setting into another type.
member.typeparam: The type to convert the value to
member.param: If the conversion fails, this value will be returned
member.returns: The converted value or defaultValue, if the conversion fails
member.remarks:
Actually, you can convert the value of the setting entry only to basic types like int, double, float and so on. In some of the next versions, there will be an interface to convert complex types into settings and the other way arround (apart from IConvertible).
This method will use the culture invariant format provider to allow you to run your web application on different server machines using different cultures.

member.summary: Allows you to describe you document, using the DublinCore scheme (DCMI Metadata Terms).

member.summary: Create a new object containing meta information.

member.summary: Serialize the information in this class to a document.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Abstraction.DublinCore.DublinCore.Title
member.summary: A name given to the resource.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Abstraction.DublinCore.DublinCore.Subject
member.remarks: Typically, the subject will be represented using keywords, key phrases, or classification codes. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. To describe the spatial or temporal topic of the resource, use the Coverage element.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Abstraction.DublinCore.DublinCore.Description
member.remarks: Description may include but is not limited to: an abstract, a table of contents, a graphical representation, or a free-text account of the resource.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Abstraction.DublinCore.DublinCore.Creator
member.summary: An entity primarily responsible for making the resource.
member.remarks: Examples of a Creator include a person, an organization, or a service. Typically, the name of a Creator should be used to indicate the entity.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Abstraction.DublinCore.DublinCore.Publisher
member.summary: An entity responsible for making the resource available.
member.remarks: Examples of a Publisher include a person, an organization, or a service. Typically, the name of a Publisher should be used to indicate the entity.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Abstraction.DublinCore.DublinCore.Coverage
member.summary: The spatial or temporal topic of the resource, the spatial applicability of the resource, or the jurisdiction under which the resource is relevant.
member.remarks: Spatial topic and spatial applicability may be a named place or a location specified by its geographic coordinates. Temporal topic may be a named period, date, or date range. A jurisdiction may be a named administrative entity or a geographic place to which the resource applies. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Thesaurus of Geographic Names [TGN]. Where appropriate, named places or time periods can be used in preference to numeric identifiers such as sets of coordinates or date ranges.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Abstraction.DublinCore.DublinCore.Date
member.summary: A point or period of time associated with an event in the lifecycle of the resource.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Abstraction.DublinCore.DublinCore.DocumentType
member.summary: The nature or genre of the resource.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Abstraction.DublinCore.DublinCore.Identifier
member.summary: An unambiguous reference to the resource within a given context.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Abstraction.DublinCore.DublinCore.Source
member.summary: A related resource from which the described resource is derived.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Abstraction.DublinCore.DublinCore.Rights
member.summary: Information about rights held in and over the resource.

member.summary: The size of the buffer used to read data from the input stream. Should be big enough to store a complete HTTP request from a client.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Configuration.MaxThreads
member.summary: The maximum number of threads in the thread pool. The number will get doubled for async I/O operation threads. If this value is too high, the server will run into performance problems due to excessive context switches. If there are many clients accessing your web server, you should increase this value to prevent congestion and to minimize response times. Increase this value, if there are "Congestion detected" entries in the logfile of the server.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Configuration.CongestionPrevention
member.summary: Enable or disable the congestion control. If there are nearly no clients accessing your web server, disabling this can improve the performance of the server slightly, but there will be the risk of a DoS attack on your server software.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Configuration.CongestionLimit
member.summary: This value will be used to determine, whether the server's thread pool is currently congested or not. If the thread pool contains more than threads.max * limit worker threads, the server will accept no more keep-alive connections.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Configuration.Protocol
member.summary: The version of the HTTP protocol which should be used for this GenHTTP webserver. HTTP/1.1 supports pipelining and other techniques to speed up the data transfer to the client. Use HTTP/1.0 for compatibility reasons.
member.remarks: Note: if you set this value to 1.1 and a client connects using the HTTP 1.0 protocol, the server will send a HTTP 1.0 response anyways.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Configuration.CompressionEnabled
member.summary: Specifiy, whether the server should compress data to send or not.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Configuration.CompressionAlgorithm
member.remarks: Actually, there is only "gzip" you can choose.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Configuration.CompressionLimit
member.summary: Responses which are smaller than this limit, will get compressed. This limit is necessary because gzip needs all the content available in RAM to compress it.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Configuration.VHostsEnabled
member.summary: Set this attribute to "false", if you want to disable vhosts.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Configuration.DocumentRoot
member.summary: The path to the project repository root.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Configuration.ServerHelper
member.summary: The path to the library containing the server helper to use.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Configuration.ServerHelperType
member.summary: The name of the class to instantiate in the assembly.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Configuration.LogToConsole
member.summary: Specify, whether the server should log information to the console or not. Enable this for debugging. Disabling the logging to the console will make the server software up to 5 times faster.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Configuration.RemotingEnabled
member.summary: Specify, whether the remoting interface should be available or not.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Configuration.RemotingPort
member.summary: Define the port which should be used for the TCP channel.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Configuration.RemotingPassword
member.summary: The hashed password required to manage the server remotely.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Configuration.StaticRegexCacheSize
member.summary: Define, how much regular expressions should be cached.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.Configuration.TimerIntervall
member.summary: Defines the intervall of the server's timer. The server will fire the timer event in this intervall.

member.name: T:GenHTTP.Abstraction.Compiling.Placeholder
member.summary: A placeholder, used in compiled documents.
member.remarks: The object framework of the GenHTTP webserver is quite slow and requires a lot of memory and CPU time. Therefor, it is recommended to compile documents so their static content is available in byte form. You can't access the document via the object framework anymore, but you can insert placeholders before you begin to compile the document. This placeholders are type-safe and can use the object framework again.

member.name: T:GenHTTP.Abstraction.DocumentType
member.summary: This enum describes the different document types, the GenHTTP object framework does support.
member.remarks:
The type of a document will influence the behaviour and the presentation of the document. For more information, see the pages of the W3C:
HTML 4.01 Specification XHTML™ 1.0 The Extensible HyperText Markup Language
Please note, that the GenHTTP object framework does neither support framesets nor HTML 5. These standards will maybe follow in later versions.

member.name: F:GenHTTP.Abstraction.DocumentType.XHtml_1_1_Strict
member.summary: Same as HTML 4.01 strict, but with a XML parseable structure. Recommended.

member.name: F:GenHTTP.Abstraction.DocumentType.XHtml_1_1_Transitional
member.summary: Same as HTML 4.01 transitional, but with a XML parseable structure.

member.name: T:GenHTTP.Abstraction.LinkType
member.summary: Describes the type of a link.
member.remarks: This enumeration provides the link types of the DTD.

member.name: F:GenHTTP.Abstraction.LinkType.Alternate
member.summary: Designates substitute versions for the document in which the link occurs.
member.remarks: When used together with the lang attribute, it implies a translated version of the document. When used together with the media attribute, it implies a version designed for a different medium (or media).

member.name: F:GenHTTP.Abstraction.LinkType.Stylesheet
member.summary: Refers to an external style sheet.
member.remarks: This is used together with the link type "Alternate" for user-selectable alternate style sheets.

member.name: F:GenHTTP.Abstraction.LinkType.Start
member.summary: Refers to the first document in a collection of documents.
member.remarks: This link type tells search engines which document is considered by the author to be the starting point of the collection.

member.name: F:GenHTTP.Abstraction.LinkType.Next
member.summary: Refers to the next document in a linear sequence of documents.
member.remarks: User agents may choose to preload the "next" document, to reduce the perceived load time.

member.name: F:GenHTTP.Abstraction.LinkType.Prev
member.summary: Refers to the previous document in an ordered series of documents.

member.name: F:GenHTTP.Abstraction.LinkType.Contents
member.summary: Refers to a document serving as a table of contents.

member.name: F:GenHTTP.Abstraction.LinkType.Index
member.summary: Refers to a document providing an index for the current document.

member.name: F:GenHTTP.Abstraction.LinkType.Glossary
member.summary: Refers to a document providing a glossary of terms that pertain to the current document.

member.name: F:GenHTTP.Abstraction.LinkType.Copyright
member.summary: Refers to a copyright statement for the current document.

member.name: F:GenHTTP.Abstraction.LinkType.Chapter
member.summary: Refers to a document serving as a chapter in a collection of documents.

member.name: F:GenHTTP.Abstraction.LinkType.Section
member.summary: Refers to a document serving as a section in a collection of documents.

member.name: F:GenHTTP.Abstraction.LinkType.Subsection
member.summary: Refers to a document serving as a subsection in a collection of documents.

member.name: F:GenHTTP.Abstraction.LinkType.Appendix
member.summary: Refers to a document serving as an appendix in a collection of documents.

member.name: F:GenHTTP.Abstraction.LinkType.Help
member.summary: Refers to a document offering help (more information, links to other sources information, etc.).

member.name: F:GenHTTP.Abstraction.LinkType.Bookmark
member.summary: Refers to a bookmark. A bookmark is a link to a key entry point within an extended document.
member.remarks: The title attribute may be used, for example, to label the bookmark. Note that several bookmarks may be defined in each document.

member.name: T:GenHTTP.Localization.LocalizationManager
member.summary: The LocalizationManager allows you to use different languages for the output of your web application.
member.remarks:
If you want to use the LocalizationManager for your own web application, you need to create a new XML file or to embedd the localization section into another XML file. Example for a localization XML file:
<localization default="deutsch"> <localization language="common"> <blubb>Blubb</blubb> </localization> <localization language="deutsch"> <welcome>Willkommen</welcome> </localization> <localization language="english"> <welcome>Welcome</welcome> </localization> </localization>

member.name: M:GenHTTP.Localization.LocalizationManager.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Create a new LocalizationManager object from a XML file.
member.param: The source file to read from

member.name: M:GenHTTP.Localization.LocalizationManager.#ctor(GenHTTP.Utilities.Setting)
member.summary: Create a new LocalizationManager from a XML section.
member.param: The source entry to read from

member.name: M:GenHTTP.Localization.LocalizationManager.LocalizeRequest(GenHTTP.HttpRequest)
member.summary: Try to find the requested localization of a .
member.returns: The localization for this request or the default localization
member.remarks: This method parses the URL of the to determine the name of the requested language. The URL has to be of this form: "/Project/language/*". If the requested file matches the regular expression, the method will redirect the request to "/Project/*" and will return the selected localization. Otherwise, the method will return the default localization.

member.name: M:GenHTTP.Localization.LocalizationManager.LocalizeRequestViaGet(GenHTTP.HttpRequest)
member.summary: Try to find the requested localization of a .
member.returns: The localization for this request or the default localization
member.remarks: This method will search for a GET field named "language" to determine the requested localization language. If the field is not set, the default localization will be returned.

member.name: M:GenHTTP.Localization.LocalizationManager.GetLocalizationOrDefault(System.String)
member.summary: Retrieve the localization for a language or the default localization, if the language is not supported by this manager.
member.returns: The localization for the given language or the default localization

member.summary: Save the XML file to disk.
member.remarks: You should only call this method if you initialized the with a XML file. Otherwise, an exception will be thrown.

member.remarks: If you set this value to a localization of another language, you will need to save this change.

member.name: M:GenHTTP.HttpResponse.IsContentCompressable(System.Int64)
member.summary: Defines, whether it makes sense to compress the content of the file, or not.
member.param: The length of the data to send
member.remarks:
Using an compression algorithm is very useful if there is plain text to send. Images and other formats (videos, binaries) are already compressed.
Large files won't get compressed because they need to be compressed before the data is sent to the client (which requires a lot of ram on big files). The size limit can be set in the server configuration file.

member.name: P:GenHTTP.HttpResponse.UseCompression
member.summary: Specifies, whether the response should be sent compressed.
member.remarks:
The client handler will set this value on initialization. Set this value to true only, if the client supports compression ().
This class will only compress plain text content types (html, css, js, ...).
